awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Nonsmooth Maps, Coupled Oscillators and Seasonal Variation of Sleep and Circadian Rhythms
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop and analyze mathematical models for circadian clock signaling and its control of sleep-wake regulation to determine how seasonality is encoded in the neural activity of the clock. Circadian (~24 hour) rhythms in behavior and physiology, including sleep-wake rhythms, are entrained by the sun's daily light cycle and affect physical and mental health. These rhythms are driven by the brain's master circadian clock, which receives light information from the eyes and coordinates biological rhythms throughout the body. In modern life, exposure to artificial light can erode the crucial tie between internal physiological rhythms and environmental light timing. The proposed mathematical modeling and data analysis projects focus on understanding how information and uncertainty in light signals are processed and stored in the master circadian clock and propagated downstream to sleep-wake networks through neural signaling.  In collaboration with a clinical researcher, the mathematical models will be applied to data describing light exposure and sleep in elementary school-aged children during the school year and summer to understand summer vacation-induced disruptions to sleep and circadian rhythms. An additional collaborator at a primarily undergraduate and Hispanic-serving institution will contribute to modeling the clock and developing a mathematical modeling mini-course for undergraduate students. Undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral trainees will be involved in the research. This project is funded jointly by the Division of Mathematical Sciences Mathematical Biology Program and the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems Neural Systems Cluster.

Behavioral states of waking, sleep, and rapid eye movement (REM) sleep are governed by networks of brainstem and hypothalamic neuronal populations, and mathematical modeling of these networks provides insights into the dynamics of their interactions. The master circadian clock in the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN) controls the timing of behavior across the 24 hour day and involves a hierarchy of physiological processes from the intracellular molecular "circadian clock," to clock-driven variations in the electrophysiological responses of SCN neurons, to the collective signaling of the SCN neural network and its dynamic role modulating sleep-wake behavior. Using an innovative combination of mathematical modeling and analysis, key aspects of light-dependent circadian modulation of sleep-wake behavior will be explored at multiple spatial and temporal scales. Return maps will be used to reduce dimensionality and formally classify the relationship between circadian signaling and bifurcations in sleep-wake patterning. Effects of coherence of SCN activity on sleep-wake behavior will be established theoretically, and these results will be applied to understand experimentally observed changes in phase relationships between dorsal and ventral SCN regions in rodents under seasonal light variation. SCN and sleep-wake network models will be combined to investigate the role of dorsal-ventral interactions in gating light effects on SCN activity; to quantify sensitivity of the human clock to erratic light schedules; and to examine mechanisms underlying summer vacation-induced changes in sleep-wake behavior in data collected in elementary school-aged children. Project results will identify potential targets for interventions to alleviate summer vacation-induced disruptions to sleep and circadian rhythms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Over the past 40 years, mathematical modeling has contributed greatly to our understanding of how external light exposure affects circadian rhythms which, in turn, influence the timing of sleep and wake episodes. The grant-supported projects developed new paradigms for mathematical models of the physiological processes generating circadian rhythms and for analyzing the dynamics of sleep-wake behavior. Specifically, we developed a new class of models for circadian rhythms based on the reduction of a network of coupled heterogeneous cellular clocks using a novel variation of the popular Ott-Antonsen ansatz tailored to data from the mammalian circadian pacemaker, the suprachiasmatic nucleus (SCN). We also developed a novel population-level firing rate model for the SCN that accounts for the non-standard firing patterns shown by SCN neurons over the circadian cycle. Additionally, we developed a suite of dynamical systems tools to analyze solutions and bifurcations of piecewise-smooth sleep-wake regulation network models. The approach leverages fast-slow decomposition to define circle maps for the timing of sleep onsets relative to the phase of the circadian rhythm drive. Tracking fixed points on the maps as relevant parameters are varied allows characterization of the bifurcations dictating changes in sleep-wake behaviors. We applied this approach to analyze the transitions between monophasic sleep (1 sleep episode per day) and biphasic sleep (2 sleep episodes per day) as occurs in young children in models that account for the 2 states of waking and sleep, and for the 3 states of waking, rapid eye movement (REM) sleep, and non-REM sleep. 

Broader Impacts: Grant projects have made significant contributions to understanding interindividual differences in response to development, pathological states such as narcolepsy, and sleep deprivation, an issue of great relevance for our 24/7 society. Grant projects assessed interindividual differences in sleep across development with a particular focus on different behavioral trajectories during the consolidation of sleep in preschool-aged children and effects of light sensitivity in early childhood. Grant projects also analyzed data to characterize sleep and circadian rhythms in children and adolescents with sleep disorders to or metabolic dysregulation. In addition, by fitting the models to experimental sleep behavior data in humans exhibiting typical long, short or regular sleep duration, grant project results show that long and regular sleepers can suffer longer lasting disruption of daily sleep patterns compared to short sleepers after sleep deprivation. These results can inform interventions to reduce the effects of sleep deprivation on perceived sleepiness and cognitive function. Additionally, grant projects used mathematical modeling to predict circadian phases from data from wearable devices tracking light exposure. The work has introduced algorithms and computing frameworks that can be implemented in clinical settings using actual patient data. These results impact the ability of health practitioners to incorporate a patient’s circadian rhythm and synchronization into health treatment plans. 

Through this collaborative grant, we established an active inter-institutional research group that provided interdisciplinary training in mathematical biology and neuroscience, dynamical systems analysis, experimental data analysis and model development to 1 postdoc, 7 graduate students and 3 undergraduate students. Weekly joint lab meetings exposed all trainees to the diverse modeling and analysis techniques employed in different grant projects, and provided a networking opportunity for the trainees from Colorado School of Mines and University of Michigan which has led to the initiation of joint trainee projects.        

In science outreach, we conducted multiple workshops on the mathematical modeling of sleep-wake behavior to high school students participating in STEM outreach programs at the University of Michigan and at Colorado School of Mines. We constructed a web-based simulator of the Two Process model (twoprocessmodel.math.lsa.umich.edu) that provides a publicly accessible, easy-to-use tool for implementation of this widely popular, classic mathematical model for the interaction of circadian and homeostatic processes regulating sleep. In the workshop, students used the simulator to analyze the recovery from sleep deprivation and to understand how the daily number of sleeps can be changed to account for sleep patterns in different animals. This workshop also introduced the concept of model parameters and provided hands-on experience with linking changes in parameters to changes in dynamics.
